text: One of my funds basically takes a return stacking approach, which obviously that's a term you've done a lot of research on and ideas that you've developed into. And the idea is just to have a core portfolio, and this is a pure beta component. And that core can be whatever you want. I have a certain blend of index funds that I use, and let's call that the benchmark. And on top of that, I'm using various income strategies as an overlay to be sort of the alpha component. I think we spoke before. You call it a portable alpha, which is kind of an interesting term. So taking this overlay and just stacking on top of your core portfolio, the mandate is simply to outperform the core. So I've called my fund enhanced index fund or enhanced beta, if you will. Almost, well, in fact, it is a buy and hold combined with an active overlay. And that's the first approach. And then the second fund, which was when we launched later, we stripped out one of our option strategies, which was a zero DTE strategy. And the unique fact about zero DTE, which stands for zero days to expiration, this intraday options with no overnight risk because everything closes out by end of day. So this second fund is a pure 100% zero DTE approach. So the idea for that is just to generate a completely non-correlated return with very tight risk management, very low drawdowns, and just a pure alpha or absolute return approach. Yeah.
